description: Identifier name used for BioSample. Max length is 50 characters.
Descriptive title for sample.
Optional description for sample.
identification or description of the specific individual from which this sample was obtained

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Source
description: At least one required: Group "Source". The natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which the sample was obtained. Use the full taxonomic name, eg, "Homo sapiens".

required_column: At least one field required. Group: At least one required: Group "Source
description: At least one required: Group "Source". Describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived.
actual mass of water vapor - mh20 - present in the air water vapor mixture
temperature of the air at the time of sampling
primary function for which a building or discrete part of a building is intended to be used
location (geography) where a building is set
carbon dioxide (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

Add terms that identify the major environment type(s) where your sample was collected. Recommend subclasses of biome [ENVO:00000428]. Multiple terms can be separated by one or more pipes e.g.:  mangrove biome [ENVO:01000181]|estuarine biome [ENVO:01000020]

Add terms that identify environmental entities having causal influences upon the entity at time of sampling, multiple terms can be separated by pipes, e.g.:  shoreline [ENVO:00000486]|intertidal zone [ENVO:00000316]

Add terms that identify the material displaced by the entity at time of sampling. Recommend subclasses of environmental material [ENVO:00010483]. Multiple terms can be separated by pipes e.g.: estuarine water [ENVO:01000301]|estuarine mud [ENVO:00002160]
device which removes solid particulates or airborne molecular contaminants

Geographical origin of the sample; use the appropriate name from this list http://www.insdc.org/documents/country-qualifier-vocabulary. Use a colon to separate the country or ocean from more detailed information about the location, eg "Canada: Vancouver" or "Germany: halfway down Zugspitze, Alps"
methods of conditioning or heating a room or building
a distinguishable space within a structure, the purpose for which discrete areas of a building is used
The geographical coordinates of the location where the sample was collected. Specify as degrees latitude and longitude in format "d[d.dddd] N|S d[dd.dddd] W|E", eg, 38.98 N 77.11 W

application of light to achieve some practical or aesthetic effect. Lighting includes the use of both artificial light sources such as lamps and light fixtures, as well as natural illumination by capturing daylight. Can also include absence of light
number of occupants present at time of sample within the given space
average number of occupants at time of sampling per square footage
total count of any organism per gram or volume of sample,should include name of organism followed by count; can include multiple organism counts
partial vapor and air pressure, density of the vapor and air, or by the actual mass of the vapor and air
Type of dataset from which the UViG was obtained
customary or normal state of the space
customary or normal density of occupants
ventilation system used in the sampled premises
Approach used to enrich the sample for viruses, if any. If more than one approach was used, include multiple ‘virus_enrich_appr’ fields.
The street name and building number where the sampling occurred
List of rooms (room number, room name) immediately adjacent to the sampling room

Aerospace structures typically consist of thin plates with stiffeners for the external surfaces, bulkheads and frames to support the shape and fasteners such as welds, rivets, screws and bolts to hold the components together, e.g., plane, glider
The unit of illuminance and luminous emittance, measuring luminous flux per unit area
An architectural structure is a human-made, free-standing, immobile outdoor construction, e.g., building, shed, home
The average of dew point measures taken at the beginning of every hour over a 24 hour period on the sampling day
Daily average occupancy of room. Indicate the number of person(s) daily occupying the sampling room
The average of temperatures taken at the beginning of every hour over a 24 hour period on the sampling day
The number of bathrooms in the building
The number of bedrooms in the building
Free-living or from host (define relationship)

The building design, construction and operation documents, e.g., building information model, commissioning report, complaint logs, contract administration, cost estimate, janitorial schedules or logs, maintenance plans, schedule, sections, shop drawings, submittals, ventilation system, windows
The age of the built structure since construction
The characterization of the location of the built structure as high or low human density, e.g., urban, rural
A physical structure that is a body or assemblage of bodies in space to form a system capable of supporting loads
The area of the ceiling space within the room
The physical condition of the ceiling at the time of sampling, e.g., new, visible wear, needs repair, damaged, rupture
The type of material used to finish a ceiling, e.g., drywall, mineral fibre, tiles, PVC, plasterboard, metal, fiberglass, stucco, mineral wool/calcium silicate, wood
The construction format of the ceiling, e.g., wood frame, concrete

The feel, appearance, or consistency of a ceiling surface, e.g., crows feet, crows-foot stomp, double skip, hawk and trowel, knockdown, popcorn, orange peel, rosebud stomp, Santa-Fe texture, skip trowel, smooth, stomp knockdown, swirl

The ability of the ceiling to provide inertia against temperature fluctuations. Generally this means concrete that is exposed. A metal deck that supports a concrete slab will act thermally as long as it is exposed to room air flow
The type of ceiling according to the ceiling's appearance or construction, e.g., cathedral, dropped, concave, barrel-shaped, coffered, cove, stretched
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on the ceiling, e.g., presence of mold visible, no presence of mold visible
Process used to collect the sample, e.g., bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)
The cooling system identifier
The date of the last time it rained
temperature to which a given parcel of humid air must be cooled, at constant barometric pressure, for water vapor to condense into water.
The composite type of the door, e.g., metal covered, revolving, sliding, telescopic
The physical condition of the door, e.g., damaged, needs repair, new, rupture, visible wear
The direction the door opens, e.g., inward, outward, sideways
The relative location of the door in the room, e.g., north, south, east, west
The material the door is composed of, e.g., aluminum, cellular PVC, engineered plastic, fiberboard, fiberglass, metal, thermoplastic alloy, vinyl, wood, wood/plastic composite
The type of movement of the door, e.g., collapsible, folding, revolving, rolling shutter, sliding, swinging
The size of the door
The type of door material, e.g., composite, metal, wooden
The type of metal door, e.g., collapsible, corrugated steel, hollow, rolling shutters, steel plate

The type of wood door, e.g., bettened and ledged, battened, ledged and braced, battened, ledged and framed, battened, ledged, braced and frame, framed and paneled, glashed or sash, flush, louvered, wire gauged
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on a door, e.g., presence of mold visible, no presence of mold visible
The buildings architectural drawings, e.g., operation, as built, construction, bid, design, building navigation map, diagram, sketch
The number of elevators within the built structure
The number of escalators within the built structure
Estimated size of genome
The amount of exposed ductwork in the room
The number of exposed pipes in the room
Variable aspect of experimental design
The number of exterior doors in the built structure
The orientation of the exterior wall, e.g., north, south, east, west, northeast, southeast, southwest, northwest
The compass direction the exterior window of the room is facing, e.g., north, south, east, west, northeast, southeast, southwest, northwest
A firebox with chimney, e.g., gas burning, wood burning
The time period since installment of the carpet or flooring
The area of the floor space within the room
The physical condition of the floor at the time of sampling, e.g., new, visible wear, needs repair, damaged, rupture
The number of floors in the building, including basements and mechanical penthouse

The floor covering type; the finished surface that is walked on, e.g., tile, wood strip or parquet, carpet, rug, laminate wood, lineoleum, vinyl composition tile, sheet vinyl, stone, bamboo, cork, terrazo, concrete, none;specify unfinished, sealed, clear finish, paint
Refers to the structural elements and subfloor upon which the finish flooring is installed, e.g., balcony, floating floor, glass floor, raised floor, sprung floor, wood-framed, concrete
The ability of the floor to provide inertia against temperature fluctuations

Signs of the presence of mold or mildew in a room, e.g., mold odor, wet floor, water stains, wall discoloration, floor discoloration, ceiling discoloration, peeling paint or wallpaper, bulging walls, condensation
The number of times the sample location is cleaned, e.g., daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, annually
The number of times a meal is cooked per week
The types of furniture present in the sampled room, e.g., cabinet, chair, desks
The total count of hallways and cooridors in the built structure
The handidness of the individual sampled, e.g., ambidexterity, left handedness, mixed-handedness, right handedness
The location of heat delivery within the room, e.g., north, south, east, west
The method by which the heat is delivered through the system, e.g., conductive, radiant
The heating system identifier
The average carpet fiber height in the indoor environment
Name of relevant disease, e.g. Salmonella gastroenteritis. Controlled vocabulary, http://bioportal.bioontology.org/ontologies/1009 or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/mesh
NCBI taxonomy ID of the host, e.g. 9606
type of indoor surface
The recorded value at sampling time (power density)
The physical condition of the wall at the time of sampling, e.g., new, visible wear, needs repair, damaged, rupture
The last time the floor was cleaned (swept, mopped, vacuumed)
The maximum amount of people allowed in the indoor environment
Mechanical structure: a moving structure, e.g., subway, coach, carriage, elevator, escalator, boat, train, car, bus

The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation, e.g., distilled water, phosphate buffer, empty collection device, empty collection tube, DNA-free PCR mix, sterile swab, sterile syringe
The number of pets residing in the sampled space
The number of plant(s) in the sampling space
The number of individuals currently occupying in the sampling location
The type of documentation of occupancy, e.g., automated count, estimate, manual count, videos

A unique identifier of the omics-enabled observatory (or comparable time series) your data derives from. This identifier should be provided by the OMICON ontology; if you require a new identifier for your time series, contact the ontology's developers. Information is available here: https://github.com/GLOMICON/omicon. This field is only applicable to records which derive from an omics time-series or observatory.
To what is the entity pathogenic
The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive
The type and number of animals or insects present in the sampling space, e.g., cat 10, dog 2, rodent 100, snake 1
The quadrant position of the sampling room within the building, e.g., north side, west side, south side, east side
Primary publication or genome report
The recorded outside relative humidity value at the time of sampling
The sampling location within the train car, e.g., edge of car, center of car, under a seat
The rate at which outside air replaces indoor air in a given space
The unique details and component parts that, together, form the architecture of a distinguisahable space within a built structure
The condition of the room at the time of sampling, e.g., new, visible wear, needs repair, damaged, rupture, visible signs of mold/mildew
List of rooms connected to the sampling room by a doorway, e.g., attic, bathroom, closet, conference room, elevator, examining room, hallway, kitchen, mail room, office, stairwell
The total count of rooms in the built structure including all room types
The length, width and height of sampling room
Distance between doors (meters) in the hallway between the sampling room and adjacent rooms
List of room(s) (room number, room name) sharing a door with the sampling room
List of room(s) (room number, room name) located in the same hallway as sampling room
The position of the room within the building, e.g., corner room, interior room, exterior wall
The history of moisture damage or mold in the past 12 months. Number of events of moisture damage or mold observed
The net floor area of sampling room. Net area excludes wall thicknesses
Count of room occupancy at time of sampling

The horizontal sampling position in the room relative to architectural elements, e.g., north corner, south corner, west corner, east corner, northeast corner, northwest corner, southeast corner, southwest corner, center

The main purpose or activity of the sampling room. A room is any distinguishable space within a structure, e.g., attic, bathroom, closet, conference room, elevator, examining room, hallway, kitchen, mail room, private office, open office, stairwell,restroom, lobby, vestibule, mechanical or electrical room, data center, laboratory_wet, laboratory_dry, gymnasium, natatorium, auditorium, lockers, cafe, warehouse
Volume of sampling room
List of room(s) (room number, room name) sharing a wall with the sampling room
Number of windows in the room
Method or device employed for collecting sample
The floor of the building, where the sampling room is located, e.g., 1st floor, 2nd floor, basement, lobby
Processing applied to the sample during or after isolation
Sampling room number. This ID should be consistent with the designations on the building floor plans
Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected
method by which samples are sorted
The recent and long term history of outside sampling
volume (mL) or weight (g) of sample processed for DNA extraction
The weather on the sampling day, e.g., clear sky, cloudy, foggy, hail, rain, snow, sleet, sunny, windy

The season when sampling occurred. Any of the four periods into which the year is divided by the equinoxes and solstices. This field accepts terms listed under season (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C94729)
The seasons the space is occupied, e.g., spring, summer, fall, winter
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on the shading device, e.g., presence of mold visible, no presence of mold visible
The physical condition of the shading device at the time of sampling, e.g., damaged, needs repair, new, rupture, visible wear
The location of the shading device in relation to the built structure, e.g., exterior, interior
The material the shading device is composed of

The type of shading device, e.g., bahama shutters, exterior roll blind, gambrel awning, hood awning, porchroller awning, sarasota shutters, slatted aluminum, solid aluminum awning, sun screen, tree, trellis, venetian awning
Filtering pore size used in sample preparation, e.g., 0-0.22 micrometer

unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples.
The building specifications, e.g., operation, as built, construction, bid, design, photos
The mass of water vapour in a unit mass of moist air, usually expressed as grams of vapour per kilogram of air, or, in air conditioning, as grains per pound
substructure or under building is that largely hidden section of the building which is built off the foundations to the ground floor level
contaminant identified on surface
surfaces: water activity as a function of air and material moisture
surface materials at the point of sampling
water held on a surface
pH measurement of surface
temperature of the surface at the time of sampling
The recorded temperature value at sampling time outside
The subway line name, e.g., red, green, orange
The train station collection location, e.g., south station above ground, south station underground, south station amtrak, forest hills, riverside
The train stop collection location, e.g., end, mid, downtown
The building visual media, e.g., photos, videos, commonly of the building, site context (adjacent buildings, vegetation, terrain, streets), interiors, equipment, 3D scans
The total area of the sampled room's walls

The building class of the wall defined by the composition of the building elements and fire-resistance rating, e.g., frame construction, joisted masonry, light noncombustible, masonry noncombustible, modified fire resistive, fire resistive
The material utilized to finish the outer most layer of the wall, e.g., plaster, gypsum plaster, veneer plaster, gypsum board, tile, terrazzo, stone facing, acoustical treatment, wood, metal, masonry
The average height of the walls in the sampled room
The relative location of the wall within the room, e.g., north, south, east, west
The surface treatment of interior wall, e.g., painted, wall paper, no treatment, paneling, stucco, fabric

The feel, appearance, or consistency of a wall surface, e.g., crows feet, crows-foot stomp, double skip, hawk and trowel, knockdown, popcorn, orange peel, rosebud stomp, Santa-Fe texture, skip trowel, smooth, stomp knockdown, swirl
The ability of the wall to provide inertia against temperature fluctuations. Generally this means concrete or concrete block that is either exposed or covered only with paint
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on a wall, e.g., presence of mold visible, no presence of mold visible
The size of the water feature
The type of water feature present within the building being sampled, e.g., fountain, pool, standing feature, stream, waterfall
The day of the week when sampling occurred, e.g., monday, tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday, sunday
The physical condition of the window at the time of sampling, e.g., damaged, needs repair, new, rupture, visible wear
The type of window covering, e.g., blinds, curtains, none
The horizontal position of the window on the wall, e.g., left, middle, right
The relative location of the window within the room, e.g., north, south, east, west
The type of material used to finish a window, e.g., clad, fiberglass, metal, vinyl, wood
The number of times windows are opened per week
The window's length and width
Defines whether the windows were open or closed during environmental testing, e.g., closed, open
The type of windows, e.g., single-hung sash window, horizontal sash window, fixed window
The vertical position of the window on the wall, e.g., bottom, middle, top, low, middle, high
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on the window, e.g., presence of mold visible, no presence of mold visible

Optional internal field for how the BioSample submission should be named when viewed from the NCBI submission portal. If not provided, when performing submissions <--submission_name> with the suffix "-BS" will be used instead.
Optional internal field explaining the purpose of the submission for when interacting and resolving submission issues with NCBI.
